DIV1.P: THE EXAMPLE. As IT VVAS PRESEN∣ted by her Majesties Servants At the private House in Drury-Lane.
LONDON. Printed by IOHN NORTON, for ANDREW CROOKE, and WILLIAM COOKE. 1637.

DIV1.HEAD: Prologue.
DIV1.L: TWill be a great Assize, how things will hit
For us appearing at this barre of wit.
Is most uncertaine, we have nam'd our Play
The Example, and for ought we know it may
Be made one, for at no time did the lawes
However understood, more fright the cause
Of unbefriended posy, since the praise
Of wit, and judgement is not now adayes
Owing to them that write, but hee that can
Talke loud, and high, is held the witty man,
And censures finely, rules the Box, and strikes
With his court nod consent to what hee likes;
But this must bee, nor ist our parts to grudge
Any that by their place should bee a judge;
Nay, hee that in the Parish never was
Thought fit to bee o'th jury, has a place
Here, on the Bench for six pence, and dares sit,
And boast himselfe commissioner of wit,
Which though he want he can condemne with othes,
As much as they that we are the purple clothes,
Robes I should say, or whom i'th Roman state
Some ill-look'd stage-keepers, like Lictors waite
With Pipes for fasces, while another beares
Three-footed stooles in stead of Juory chaires,
This is a destiny, to which wee bow,
For all are innocent but the Poets now,
Who suffer for their guilt of truth, and arts,
And we for only speaking of their parts.
But be it so, be judges all, and bee
With our consent, but thus farre take me w'ee
If any meete here, as some men i'th age
Who understand no sense, but from one stage,
And over partiall will entaile like land
Vpon heires male all action, and command
Of voice and gesture, upon whom they love,
These, though cal'd Judges, may delinquent's prove.
But few such wee hope here, to'th rest wee say
Heare patiently ere you condemne the Play.
Tis not the authors Confidence, to dare
Your judgements, but your calme eares to prepare,
That if for mercy you can finde no roome,
Hee prayes that mildly, you pronounce his doome.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus. 1.

SP.SPEAKER: SOl.
SP.L: Dormant, why Dormant, thou eternall sleeper!
Who would be troubled with these lethargies about him?
Dormant, are you come Dreamer.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Would I were so happie, ther's lesse noyse in a Steeple upon a Coronation, ohsleepe, sleepe, though it were a dead one, would be comfortable; your worship might please to let my fellow Oldrat watch, as well as I.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: Oldrat? that fellow is a drone.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Hee has slept this halfe hower, on the Iron Chest, would I were in my grave to take an nappe, Death would doe me a courtesie, I should be at rest, and heare no noyse of Dormant.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Nothing but a yawne sir, I doe all that I can to keepe my selfe waking.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Tis done consideratelie, this heavie dulnesse,
Is the disease of soules, sleepe in the night,?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Shall I wake my fellow Oldrat, he is refresht

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Doe, but returne you with him, I have businesse with both.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: To heare us joyne in our opinion, of what's a clocke, they talke of Endimion, now could I sleepe three lives.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: When other men measure the howers with sleepe,
Careles of what they are, and whom they trust,
Exposing their condition to danger
Of plotts, I wake, and wiselie thinke prevention,
Night was not made to snore in, but so calme
For our imaginations, to be stirring
About the world, this subtle world, this world
Of plotts, and close conspiracie, there is
No faith in man, nor woman, wher's this Dormant?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Here is the sleepie vermine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Oh come hither; surra, wher's your Ladie?

SP.SPEAKER: Ol.
SP.L: Out all this night at play sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: All night, ther's some plot, but I am safe
At home, your gaming Ladies are strange Whirligigs,
But while she plaies, and revells with the gallants,
Here I am cabled up, above their shott,
And see in my imagination all there plotts,
Nay, we are the quietest couple, never meet,
No▪ not a bed, there may be plotts in that,
This part o'th house is mine, and here I walke
And see the soule, the verie soule o'th world.

SP.SPEAKER: Old.
SP.L: It has bin Daie this two howers.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Then tis time for me to goe to bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Would my hower were come once.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Keepe out daie light, and set up a fresh taper,

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: By that time we have din'd, he'le have slept his first sleepe.

SP.SPEAKER: Old.
SP.L: And after supper call for his breake-fast.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Yo're sure 'tis morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: As sure as I am sleepie—

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: And that your Ladies not come in?

SP.SPEAKER: Old.
SP.L: As sure as I have the Key.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Is my Neece readie?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Two howers agoe sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: So earlié? there may bee a plott in that, say
Her uncle would speake with her, I use every morning,
Before I goe to bed, to give her counsell,
In her husbands absence, shee is young, and hansome,
And there be plottsith world. Dormant, come hither.
What Gentlemen doe frequentlie come hither?
Who does visit her most?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: My Ladie sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: My Neece Iaintha sirra, for my wife
I will let her alone of purpose yet,
To minde her game, shuffle, and cut, and dice,
And daunce the brawles, they cannot cosen me.
Say my intelligence, who does visit most
My Kins-woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: The gay Lords often with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Who?

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.L: He that comes everie morning like S. George.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: I do not saie to mount her, the Lord—

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Fitzaverice.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: The same, sir hee's the most bountifull Gentleman and makes us all soe praie for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: More plotts, he has a vast estate, and though
Fame speake him noble, I suspect he loves her.
He has my Nephews Land is morgage too.
A mere device, I adome it, come hither,
Let not the arras heare us, saie what pranke
Of mischeife, has he done, he should be bountifull
To thee? on what suspition canst deserve it?
Come be ingenious, and confesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Who I be ingenious? alas you are deceived.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Be free, this grome conspires.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Doe I looke like one that would be ingenjous?

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: What noyse is tha? more plotts, let me enter,
They are sawcie with my dores, tis well they are
All hart of Oake, and sound to endure the Knocking.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: I heare my Ladies foot-man call the Porter.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: I'le keepe no Gate that will be knockt o'this fashon
I thinke it were a speciall pollicy
To have a kinde of a wheele; or turning Engine
Advanc'd before my dore, and admit none
Without a Ticket.

SP.SPEAKER: Old.
SP.L: My Lady is come sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Is shee alone?

SP.SPEAKER: Old.
SP.L: The Gentleman that complements with my Lady,
And is here halfe an howre before my Lord still—

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Master Confident?

SP.SPEAKER: Old.
SP.P: The same, he manns her Ladiship, and she is comming this way through the Gallery.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Was ever such an impudence? she wonot carry
Him to her Chamber? new Plotts, obscure me hangings.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Master Confident, and Ly Plott.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: I shall report how much his Lordship owes
For this most noble favour,

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Hee deserues,
By many bounties ever to command me,
And I must thanke your paines, but in my Chamber,
We may discourse more freely.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: You much honour me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Bountie, and Lordships, and discourse in Chambers?
This fellow is a rascall, new new Plotts,

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: If your worship meane to lie with her Ladiship—

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: By noe meanes.
How happie am I, that we keepe severall quarters,
Some husband would torment himselfe with watching,
Skrue his Nose in at a Key-hole, or in some crannie
Wedge his long eare, let'em alone, it makes,
It makes, and my lascivious Gamster finde his plotts discovered,
All his wit, gleand from Italian Sonetts? and loose times;
His bouncing, aud his braves shall not disguise
His hart from me, I see't, I see't allready,
And laugh that I am alone, and have my humor.
Oh, tis my Neece, away and dresse my Pillow.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Good morrow sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Morrow? 'tis now my bedd time.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: You were pleasd.
To send for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: I did deare Neece.
Before I goe to sleepe, I must commend
Advices to thee, 'tis part of my devotion,
In breife, because the Day comes fast upon me,
Have a great care you be not seene too publicke,
Your Chamber's spacious enough to walke in,
Ther's danger in society, and the World
Is full of plotts,

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: What plotts?

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: I know not, but
Be solitarie as I am, and be safe.
Your husbands debt's have made him quit his Countrie,
He was an unthrift, nay I spare him not
Although he were my kins-man, 'twas ill done,
Whose plott so ere it were, to loose your Joynture,
Times are necessitous, but while he drills
His men abroad, take heed you meete not hotter
Service at home, there be fine Lords ith World,
And Gentlemen that runne, and carry messages,
And Pages, that bring Jewells, and can whisper
The baudy poesies, and soe-forth.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: You are not; Jealous of mee

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Nor of my wife, I lie
Alone discreetlie, let my Madam plaie,
Sit up a nights and gamboll,

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: And dee love her?

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: At distance, as becomes a polliticke man,
That would not sell his state to buy an heire,
Our lookes so seldome doe converse, that if
We should engender at the eyes, she wod
Not teeme so often as an Elephant, fooles diet with
There wives and be in danger of provocatives
To friske, and mount the table, precious pastime!
Come thou art happie; that thy husbands absence
Hath given thee occasion to be solitarie,
Trust not the aie abroad by my example.
Take heede of plotts, and soe good-night.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Good morrow.
I thanke you for your counsell but it needs not,
I pittie the condition of this Gentleman,
That makes his life a penance to seeme wise,
He talkes of plotts, and is the greatest enemie
To himselfe with his vaine feares, but why do I
Discourse of miserie without my selfe,
That carrie in my bosome everie minute,
All that can make a woman miserable?
Thought of my husband wounds me, yet I cannot
Be suffered to injoy it, like a Deere
I am chas'd by forraine Hunters, and not left
To thinke what crueltie at home persues me.
SP.STAGE: Enter her woman and a Page.
SP.L: You might have knowne my pleasure, in good manners,
Ere you admitted anie.

SP.SPEAKER: Wo.
SP.L: Tis but a Page Madam, the poore child
Wants yeeres to offend.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: He serves the Lord Fitzamorous
Beshrew your diligence.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: Who commends to your
Faire hand these Jewells Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I preethe carrie 'em backe, their insid's poyson,

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: I would not be corrupted with the one,
To betraie tother so, they cannot fright
When you examine, if you knew his Lordship
Soe well, as I would wish, you would accept
And cherish these presentments, y'are the first
Ladie within my observation,
That has tooke time, to aske her conscience
The meaning of a Jewell, sent by a Lord,
A yong and hansome Lord too; 'tis a thing
At Court, is not in fashion, and 'twere pittie
One with so good a face, should be the presedent,
Of such superfluous modestie.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Does your Lord
Instruct you thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: We take it of our selves,
Pages and waiting women are apt by nature
To understand their office, you may be confident,
My Lord meanes honorably, and as becomes
A Gentleman of high bloud, he will visite
Your Lady-ship.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I shall not neede, returne him then my thankes,
By messenger.

SP.SPEAKER: Pag.
SP.L: I apprehend,
And wish you a morning faire as your owne beautie,
My humblest dutie.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: How blacke sinne doth scatter
Her seede betimes, and every ground is fruitfull.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Has shee the Paper?

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: And the jewell too.

SP.SPEAKER: Wo.
SP.L: I know sheele chide me, but his Lordships
Bounty commands I should bee serviseable.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Away, and wantonnesse inspire me, Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: More rude intrusions?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Patience noble Madam,
The message that I bring, is more calme and gentle
Then the coole winde, that breathes upon the Flowers
Soft kisses in the Spring, the woollen feete
Of time doe move with a lesse noyse, then mine
Beneath this happy Roofe, vouchsafe your eare,
And words shall meete your sense, and Court it with
Swifter delight then apprehension
Knows how to reach, and when I have let fall
Love, which doth make all language rich, and told you
His name that gives his life up in my breath,
To be made blest by being yours, you'le wish
I were all voyce, and to that harmony,
Chaine your owne soule for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: What doe you meane
By this strange language? pray bee cleerer, sir,
If you direct it to my understanding.
VVhat is your businesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: I have tol'd you, Madam.
Love.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: What love I beseech you sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: A love that doth include in his owne flame
What Poets made but fiction in the gods,
When Earthlie beauties tempted them from Heaven,
A fire which from the bosome of loves preist
Shoots up religion and a sacrifice
To what his soule adores, a glorious love,
And love of you.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Of me? it will concerne
That I should know him.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Had his person bin
A stranger, so much worth, and fame preferrs him
To every noble knowledge, that you cannot
Be ignorant, what wonder of mankinde
I point at, hath report brought to your eare
I'th stacke of men, one that hath had the praise
Of wit, of valour, bountie, a faire presence,
A tongue to inchant heaven? these waite one him,
As he, to be your servant: he is a man
(What pittie it is I cannot call him more)
The pride, and darling both of warre, and peace,
The Lord of many Worlds.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: How sir! He may be bountifull indeed then.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: With your pardon,
Shall we allow to everie common man
A little world, and not thinke him worth manie,
Who hath the price of thousands in himselfe?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: What miracle is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: He is a man
Soe full of all, that thought, or love can be
Ambitious of, that nothing can deserue him,
But shee alone that hath in her owne frame
Of woman, all that ever praised the sex,
And these are all your owne, make him so too,
And from your loves, the decay'd world shall hope
To see a race of Demi-gods.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I finde not
By all these markes of honour and of goodnesse
What person you commend thus

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: Can there be anie beside my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Your Lord may be
Besides himselfe after soe great a Character.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: The Lord Fitzavarice.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Cry mercie sir,
I know him, and you might with halfe the expence
Of so much wit in blanke verse, have exprest
His purpose, and himselfe, I thanke him hartelie,
But am not so much worth, pray tell him so.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Ladie, I doe not use to thrive so ill
In my love-undertakings.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I'st your Trade?
It seemes so, by your prompt and elegant way,
Are you soliciter generall for other's,
In love, ti'd by your place, never to move
Conditions for your selfe? he is but a Lord
Whose fame you have advanc'd thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: You'r right, Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.P: And I was never taught, that witt or handsomenesse are assur'd by patent, dee thinke this Lord
SP.L: May not finde his peeres?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: No question, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: This would well be a double Knave.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: There may be Gentlemen,
That owe no high and mightie titles, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: As gracious with a Lady;

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: And as active;

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: With wit, with valour, bountie, a faire presence,
And tongue to inchant heaven.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: As I would wish,
I onely was ambitious to enjoy her
After my Lord, if once shee were corrupted?
Venus send me good lucke, and I be
His taster, but hee's here.
Trust mee an other time.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Hast prevail'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: I have taken off the impossibilitie,
Or shee deceives me much: To her your selfe,
Ile take my opportunitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Still Melancholie?
What dee meane Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I have kept a Jewell for your Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Will shee come too't allready?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: And because
I would not be held guiltie of ingratitude,
Not furnish'd with a gift worth your acceptance,
I must present your owne agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Why this
I sent you, Madam, doe not so dishonour mee,
I have plenty of these trifles sha't have more,
Richer and brighter to attend thy beautie,
Here they will shine in their owne place.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I dare not accept of any, they are dangerous.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: They are not poyson'd.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Yes more killing then
The teeth of Serpents, or the Vipers blood,
Without a charme, they had ere this undone me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Pray make your sense familiar to me.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Can you seeme ignorant, by whose direction
They were sent hither, oh my Lord, but thinke,
What honour you can gaine out of my ruines.
Why doe you still persue me with this heate
Of sensuall fame, and send these tempters to me,
After so many vowes, to keepe my faith,
And name unstain'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Still in these foolish humors?
What did you marrie for?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: To enjoy my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Enjoy him in his absence then by proxie.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: VVhen he is absent from my hart, may
Consent to be as blacke, as you would make me;
But while he hath a constant dwelling here,
I must loose both at once, if I forsake him.
Oh thinke upon your selfe my Lord, and make
Your title good, and justifie, that honour
By our selves acquir'd, is richer, then what blood,
And birth can throw upon us, send noe more
Agents to plead your shame, their errand is
So foule, it must infect 'em, to be false,
Even to your selfe, my husband is abroad
To farre from home.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Hee's fighting i'th low-Countries,
By his example you may Skirmish here,
A litle, if you please, I doe not wish him
Return'd, although I have his land in mortgage,
If you would bee lesse cruell, you may pay
His debt in other propertie, and cancell
The payment in due time.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I'le heare no more.
You have a stayned soule.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: I doe love this Ladie,
As Gentlemen now call love, and that extremelie.
Shee is all nunns flesh about her, but has the Divell
No tricke to thaw her chastitie? I must have
Some way to enjoy her body for my credit,
The world takes notice I have courted her,
And if I mount her not, I loose my honour.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus Secundus.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: So, so, now wee are furnish'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Our acts and deeds are to shew for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Scr.
SP.L: Sigillatum et deliberatum in praesentia not ari.
Publici. I thanke you Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: In the presence of the notorious Publican.
But dee heare, who shall pay backe the monie?

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: VVhat mony?

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: The mony wee ha taken up to goe a wooing to
This Kick-shaw.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: Share and share like, how ever, the securitie
Is good, and the Scrivener satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: I have great minde—

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: To pay it all, shat have my voyce.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Vpon condition the Lady would seale to
Covenants, you should finde me reasonable.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: For that we must take our fates, one of
Vs is sure to carry her against the World.
He that has least wit, has five hundred
Pound a yeere, if that, good clothes, and a
Handsome man with appurtenances, cannot
Tempt an elder sister, would shee were sent
To a Nunnery, lets loose noe time, but advance to her instantlie,

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Stay I have it, and no unhappy invention,
A divice, if the worst come to the worst,
You will thanke mee sort.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: What ist?
Mercury himselfe be the Doctor Mid-wife, and
Deliver thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: The gentlewoman we aime at, has a great
Estate, a fortune for a Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: All this I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: She has many Sutors,

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: So much the worse, proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: But none in grace, makes her selfe merry with'em,
And jeeres'em mainlie, cannot love.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: What comfort is this for us?

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Now I come too't, wee two doe love this Lady,

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: No matter for that, toth'poynt
Wee come a wooing to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Tis not possible
Wee should both draw the prise, but one can bee
Her husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: Of us two, right.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: And yet in our particular,
Ther's none of us can say, he shall prevaile,
And be the man, the man, that must be Lord
Of the estate, justle the noble-Men. And domineere.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: What of all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Now marke mee,
He that shall conquer this Virginian Iland
And write himselfe Lord of the Golden-mines,
Will have a very fine time on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: Very likelie, what's the conclusion?

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Nay tell me first, what will
Become of him that must
Sit downe with a willow Garland, that has seal'd
For a thousand pounde; with what deare appetite
Shall hee discharge the Scrivener?

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: One on's must loose, unlesse we could devide her.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Then I have thought a way to make us both
Gayners, in some proportion.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: That were a tricke worth our learning.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Play your Cards wisely, and 'tis done.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: As how prethy?

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Why thus
Hee that shall marry her of us two,
As one of us must speed, shall enter Bond
At's marriage, to give the other a thousand pound,
This composition may be allowed and sealed to,
If you consider, something will be requisite,
For them, that goe without the maiden-head,
Debts and devises will grow due, and Sacke
Will not be unnecessary, to forget her health in,
What thinke you on't? and who e're obtaines the Lady
Will have no cause to grumble at this motion,
Is not this equall and a certainety for both?

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: Let the Articles be drawne, 'tis a safe bargaine,
Hee's my hand too't.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: A match, the writings,
Will quickly bee prepared, for things must carry
Formality and law, we doe but talke else,
Va Withall my hart, subscribe to night, who's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Tis Confident.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: My two ingenious sparkes, my Landed witts,
And therefore more miraculous, what makes
Your lookes exalted, as if Venus were
Propitious now?

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: Thart right we are in love.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: I knew't, I read thy Caracter in your brow,
I see the desperate Archer in each eye,
Prepar'd with golden Shafts to wound your mistresses,
Their harts must bleed, no destiny will helpe it,
You two are Cupids darlings, and hee's bound
To bring you all the Ladies you can wish for,
Humble and suppliant for the Game.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Dost thinke wee shall prevaile then?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Have I ambition
To be your honorer, and o'th nuptiall night
Light up my epihalamy, to inflame
Your bosomes, and instruct your wanton limbes
The activitie of love beyond fierce Aretine.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: But dost heare! we are both suters to one Lady;
Which dost thinke shall carry her?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: To the same Lady!

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: Thou knowest her,
Jacintha, Lady Peregrines sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: The glory of her sex, yau'e plac'd your thoughts,
With a discreete ambition.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Who shall have her dost thinke?
Speake thy opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: You, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: shall I?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Can you appeare doubtfull?
Be not so much ingrate to natures bountie,
Each part about you in silent oratorie
May plead toth Queene of Love, yau'e to much excellence,
Were all your other graces worne in Clouds,
That eye, that very eye, would charme a Lucrece,
And by the golden unresisted Chaines
Draw up her soule, and melt it in your bosome,
Your presence is a volume of inchantements,
But move, and every beauty falls before you,
But if you speake, which needs not to obtaine,
You give a louder notice to the World,
Then when you list, you conquer, and create
One accent of your tongue, able to make
A Nyobe returne from her cold Marble,
And spring more soft and active then the Aire
To court your amorous breath.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: Hum no more, if thou loust me, we are upon
A composition, hee that winnes the Lady
Shall give the other a thousand pound:
If you make him confident to bee preferrd,
Hee'le never signe to'th' Covenant.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: How prefer'd?
Vnder what misconstruction have I suffer'd?
Although I name it justice, he should challenge
The mistresse of his thoughts, can you want merit
Who live the example of all wit, to boast
A victorie in your love? were I a woman
(As nature only hudles into the world When shee sends forth a man) give me licence
To expresse my thoughts, and had all that invention
And truth could adde, to advance me to opinion,
I should bee hono'rd to be writ your servant,
And call obedience to you, greater triumph,
Then to be Empresse of an other world,
You have so rich a wit, that dotage may
Bee justified upon't, and nothing but
A soule purg'd from all dreggs, and quitted from
Mortalitie, can lay a worthie claime to't.
Yau'e put a question would afflict an Oracle
To understand, and answer, which of you
Should triumph o're a Lady, I am madd
When I consider the necessitie
Of fate, that one of you must be accepted,
And both so bounteoussie deserving. Then,
If I pronounce agen that both must have her,
You'le pardon my ambition, Gentlemen,
Which levells with your wishes.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Could I speake thus,
I would not thanke the Ladie should run madd for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: Jack prethe lett's fancie him,
Hee has spoke home and handsomelie.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Let it be five peeces, oh witt of witts!

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: You have, Gentlemen.
A care to enlarge my Librarie, I translate
These into bookes, whose title-page shall owne
Your name in shining Capitalls.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Drinke, drinke Sack.
And divine the world with thine owne wit, t'will sell,
Hang other bookes, woot never switch a Play up?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Las the Comedians have no soule to speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: Naie doe not leave us.
We are going to this Lady, shee randevou's
To day at Lady Plotts, we shall have musicke, and dancing
Youle meete my Lord there

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: I am his creature, and your humble servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: Nay no distinction.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: What braines some men have?
I would change all my acres for his Poetrie.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Plott.
SP.L: Still peevish!

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Most invinciblie, no temptation
Can fasten on her, wood I had nere laid seige to her,
The taking of her province, will not be
So much advantage to mee, as the bare
Removing of my seige will loose me credit.
I would she were recoverable by Law,
There were some hope by vexing my estate,
And tiring Westminster, within few Termes
A gentleman might come to issue with her,
If all were of her minde, what would become on's?
Lent, everlasting lent would mortifie
Our masculine concupiscence, and not leave
The strongest body worth an egge at Easter.

SP.SPEAKER: Plo.
SP.L: I am glad your Lordship yet is pleasant with
Her stubbornesse, and were I worthie to
Advise you, it should never trouble your thoughts;
I know your Lordship is not barren of acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: There be more Ladies in the World,
And of the Game.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: The Game my Lord? I hope,
You point not this at me, because I use
To passe the howrs at play with Ladies, and gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: At Dice and Cards? you have more charitie,
Then to thinke I accuse your Ladyship,
Though there be some have dar'd to venture both ways
Vpon record, yet seeme stanch to the world,
I and are thought to pray sometimes, I wod-not
For the Indies tempt your Ladiship, I know
You are deafe to all leaud accents.

SP.SPEAKER: Plo.
SP.L: Tis your goodnesse—

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Never to try thee, tis fit only such
As your cold kins-woman, wenches that have
No spirit should be tempted to those sports;
Nor is shee otherwise considerable
To me, more then my charitie may restore her,
I pitie a hansome woman should eate chalke,
And die i'th fullens, if she might be comforted, and cured.

SP.SPEAKER: Plo.
SP.L: With a Warme bed-fellow?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Y'are right, Madam,
But shees here, and her elder sister.
There is an other Lady I would not touch now,
I meane i'th leaud way, shee has life and fire,
And moves without an Engine, give me a wench,
That I must mould into a wanton shape,
And quicken her to aire by my owne Art,
A wench that must be purg'd, sublim'd, calcin'd,
By'th chymistrie of Love, till shee become
A glorified spirit, and acknowledge
Shee tooke her exaltation from me;
In that I glorie more, then to have perfected
The Magisterium, and boast the Elixar.
But I waste time.

SP.SPEAKER: Plo.
SP.L: This I cannot helpe,
He wonot understand.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Can you worke, Ladie,
No cure upon your sister by the example
Of your free hart?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: My Lord I chide her for't,
Tell her what follie 'tis, to wast her health
With feeding so much melancholie, I wish
Shee had my constitution; to laugh
At all the World.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: You are satyricall.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: No matter what men thinke of me: my Lord,
I am no great admirer of their virtues.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: You doe not hate us, Ladie?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: But with pardon
Of your Lordship, it is possible, I may never
Runne madd for Love.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: You doe converse with us.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Because I have
As yet, no resolution to bee cloistred:
Sometimes men stirre my pitie, but most commonlie
My laughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Y are a strang condition'd Gentlewoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: I would be so my Lord, to all that love mee,
And love my selfe the better, for that humor.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: You'le never marrie?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Certainlie, not while I have any wit,
And can buy follie at a cheeper rate.
My sister has taught me; that Ladie has
A precious husband too, shall I, my Lord,
Bee bold to aske you, but one question,
What are men good for?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Pray, Ladie, doe not feare I come a wooing.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Your Lordships mirth offends not mee in this.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Yet if I could love, I would marrie thee
Of all women alive.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Your Lordship should
Have litle cause, I hope, to wish so ill to mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: What sayes my Lady Aprill here, all showrs?

SP.SPEAKER: Plo.
SP.L: My Lord is a great honorer of your sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Tis his fault in my conscience, but I hope
Shee'le have a care, poore soule.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Let mee prepare you,
And when you see me close with Madam Plott,
You may advance.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Bee breife.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: Most noble Ladie.
I have no time to enlarge my selfe; your fat's
In danger, if discretion sit not at
The Helme, with love; the Gentlemen, that next
Present themselves, are not to bee admitted
Guests to your bosome, in the yet darke booke
Of destinie, there is a name reseru'd,
To make you happie, your Starrs guide you to
A husband, worthy of this blood, and beautie:
Thinke on the Prophet.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: Now wee may come in.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Bright Ladie, make your humble servants proud
To kisse your white hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Not to fast, Gentlemen,
You doe not meane to marrie mee; some aire,
Or i'le goe tak't abroad: two to one woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: The lot gave mee prioritie, you know,
Therefore obey your chance, I must first court her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: These are the guests hee talk'd on sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: What shall I doe now?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Fall in with the chamber-woman, that is a way
To know the ebbe, and flowing of her Mistresse,
Saile by that winde I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: The truth is, Ladie,
I love you in the noble way of Marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: I am sorry for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Why my prittie Mistresse?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: I cannot love that way.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Are you in earnest?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Doe you take mee for a Jester?

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Doe but name
The way you have the most minde to bee loved in;
The high way, or the by way, any way,
I am at your service.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: What is that Gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: One that would be in love too,
If he had an apprehension
You'd favour him, a thing has neither witt
Nor honestie, he would needs come along,
I could not shake him off, without a quarrell,
You'le quickelie finde his barrennesse, and dismisse him:
He has bin practising this fortnight, how
To make a legge, that learned Gentleman
Knowes the inside of his soule, for my owne part—

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Methinks he is a very handsome man.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Should he but heare you, Ladie, he would thinke
You jeer'd him fearefullie.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: And he may have a generous minde. What's his estate?

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: How's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: If you doe love me, give him opportunitie
To-tell me his poore minde alitle.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: I obey.
Shees taken with him, and the worst come
To the worst, there will be a thousand pound good yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: So resolute?

SP.SPEAKER: Plo.
SP.L: That man must have a powerfull tongue must charme her,
Into consent of marriage, her estate
Is worth ten thousand pound.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: A glorious summe,
Able to whet ambition, now the others
Turne is, to shew himselfe ridiculous.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: I tell you in three syllables, I love you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: That gentleman professes the same language,
Your friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: My friend? hee's none of mine, true wee have bin
Acquainted, met, fell into conference of you,
And came together, Ladie, he is no man
Of that cleere fame, to ingage my serious friend-ship,
A verie puff-fist.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: What's that I praie?

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: A Phantome, a meere Phantome.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Phantome, what's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: A mentall Tiphon, a windie capruch, I doe grace him,
Or so, but he is the impudent'st fellow—

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Hee speakes well
Of you, gave you a worthie Character.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: Hee cannot choose.
He knowes me well enough, and all the world,
Besides I have a temper must not bee
Provok'd with calumnies, tis true hee has some
Pretty parts, is held an excellent scholler, can sing,
And daunce, and manage a Horse well,
Hee's borne of a good familie, can speake,
When hee lists, to purpose too, I confesse it,
But what's all this when a man will bee a rascall?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: What blessed paire of customers have I got?
These would make excellent husbands, and love me
To'th purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Well, remember, you have promis'd,
Vpon condition, I dismisse you now,
To give mee an other answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: My good Lord,
I have an humble suite to you, I should aske
First how your hopes thrive in that sullen Ladie.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo,
SP.L: I must expect, but what's your businesse, to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: In breefe, to advance my service to
That Ladie, by your Honors testimonie
Of what I may deserve, I am confident
I shall reward it, by securing her
Faire sister to your wishes, shees your owne,
Or if shee prove too honest, I shall make
A recompence by offering to your pleasure,
The other, who by authoritie of your breath,
May make me Lord of her, and her full fortune,
You understand, my gracious Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: I doe so.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Va. Your Lordships humble creatures.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: I am your servant.
What shall wee doe, Ladies? but I forget,
I have something more to say to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: To me, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Your clyents increase, Ladie,
That gentleman tells me, he does love you, and would marry you.
Because I have obseru'd his nature, I'le
Give him in breefe, he is a fellow will
Vndoe thee in a fortnight, though not in
Thy estate, yet in thy minde, a greater mischiefe.
If thou dost marrie him, it will be pollicie,
To turne witch betime, ere he sell thee o're to shame,
And so much povertie, the Divell wonot
Trust thee with a familiar, now beleeve him,
Wee droupe methinks—

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: So, so, here are an other couple, who shall trust
Mankinde? it will be a miracle to finde
One honest man i th bundle, sir, you are
Bound to my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: His least favours to mee
Are more then my whole life can satisfie,
Oh Ladie, if you knew him but as I doe,
You would be lost in wonder of his goodnesse.
Bove all, he is adorer of chast truth,
And speakes religiouslie of any man.
Hee will not trust obscure traditions,
Or faith implicite, but concluds of things
Within his owne cleare knowledg what hee sayes,
You may beleeve, and pawne your soule uppon't.
Vouchsafe mee kisse your faire hand, whose least touch
Consented to though I were old and dying,
Would quicken mee into a Spring.

SP.SPEAKER: Plo.
SP.L: You forget, my Lord, the musicke was prepar'd
To daunce, and warme her blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Each take his Ladie

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Falstasse I will beleeve thee,
There is noe faith in vilanous man.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Beginne there.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Lady Bellamia, as taking opportunity to goe to her chamber, Enter Lady Plott, and Fitzavarice.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Follow her, my Lord, she is stolen to her chamber: thi wil
Give you admittance through my Lodgings, I'le excuse
Your absence, there bee more wayes to'th wood, trie all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: How much you blesse mee, shee shall want noe triall,
This opportunitie is worth an Empire.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus Tertius.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: What shall I say? consent, deere Ladie, to
Be mine, and thou shat tast more happinesse,
Then womans fierce ambition can persue;
Shift more delights, then the warme-spring can boast
Varietie of leaves, or wealthie harvest
Graine from the teeming earth. Joy shall dry all
Thy teares, and take his throne up, in thy eies,
Where it shall sit, and blesse what e're they shine on.
The night shall Sowe her pleasures in thy bosome,
And morning shall rise only to salute thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Enough, too much. My Lord, I hop'd when last
Your importunitie inforc'd my promise
Of other answer, I should never see you,
If being a sad prisoner to my chamber,
Might have prevented your accesse: but since
I am betraid to this discourse, receive
What the necessitie of fate compells to.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Another answer?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Yes, but such an one
As must at least challenge affinitie
With what I said before: not your estate,
Though multiplied to Kingdomes, and those wasted
With your invention, to serue my pleasures,
Have power to bribe my life away from him,
To whose use I am bid to weare it; be yet just,
And seeke no further to pollute the streame
Of my chast thoughts, Ile rather choose to die
Poore wife to Peregrine, then live a Kings
Inglorious strumpet, can you thinke my Lord,
Should I give up my freedome to your bende,
And for the pride of wealth, sell woman in mee,
(For she must loose that name, that once turnes whore)
Could I arrive at impudence enough
To come abroad, and not be mou'd to heare
My shame from every tongue, but scorne my infamie,
(As tis the nature of this sinne to strengthen
It selfe still with a greater) could you thinke,
If noe religion can correct your wildnesse,
Anothers price, or pleasure, would not buy mee
Even from your armes? there is no faith in lust,
And she that dares be false to one she loves,
Will twine with all the world, and never blush for't,
Kisse, and betraie as often. Thinke on this,
And call your selfe home,

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Lady, I have heard you,
And doe allow the excuse, I doe not urge,
Although your husbands absence may plead for't,
You should be generallie at my dispose,
Disclaime all place, and person, but what's mine,
I am not so ambitious, my desires
Are humble, and beg only so much favour
To admit me to one service, (you know what
To understand by it) and if you like not
My activitie handsomelie, discharge mee agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Worse then infection, how dare you speake
This blasphemie to honor, or I heare it?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: I'ts not to be avoyded, I have secur'd
Your Chamber, Ladie.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Innocence defend mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Once more, and nature worke,
You say you love your husband, and account
His absence the misfortune, that doth sit
Most heavie on your soule, this is increas'd
By the dispaire of his returne; since all
Hop's fed, to satisfie his deepe ingagements,
Which threaten ruine here, I have a mortgage
Of his, for summs lent by my thriving father,
Your joynture, (but releast by you, I take it)
I am so much a servant to thy beautie,
The first night I embrace thy delicate bodie,
The Lands thy owne agen, a round encouragement.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: What doe I heare?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: If Lords should pay so deare for every capering,
T'wou'd trie the backe of their estate: but marke mee,
I ha not done, summe up his other debts,
They swell to thousands, be but faire condition'd,
For everie time thou admitst mee after, to thy
Pillow, I'le strike of an hundred pound,
Till all the debts be unravel'd: In the meane time
Thy husband shall returne, and walke the Towne,
Free as an Alder-man, and be mace-proofe,
Shall live, and lie with thee, and love thee too,
And praise thee for this noble composition,
What saist? I finde thy wisedome comming to thee.
Should it be knowne, who'le thinke the worse of thee?
Alas, good soule, 'twas pure love to thy husband,
They must imagine, wrought with thee. What woman
But would to save a husbands life, and fortune,
Venture a trifle? nay they shall commend
Thy act, and reade the storie to their children▪
And envy the example was not theirs,
I shall have all the blame, but i'le endur't
For thy sake, all the tyrannie will be mine,
But to secure thy peace, and doe thy husband
A curtesie, I'le runne a thousand hazards.
Doe I appeare now?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Yes, a glorious monster.
Good Heaven!

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Once more, will you consent?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Neveroh, never: let mee tell you, sir,
You have so litle prevail'd upon my Love,
That allmost I forget my charitie
Y'are a bad man: I'le sooner meet a basiliske, and be one.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Nay then.—Hee drawes his Poynard.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: What doe you meane?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: If soft intreaties
With all that man can promise, move you not
To the delight, I'le snatch it from your bosome,
Nay never shake, I'le change that modest palenesse
Into a blush, shall speake thy blood as hot
As myne, or leave thy veines dry as the face
Of earth, when winter hath deflowred her cheeke,
And seal'd up all her beauties in a frost.
Ha, Madam, dead, helpe: I did but trie thee,
My Ladie Plott, a curse upon your Plotts.
Jacintha, Ladies, I am undone, no helpe?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Peace you'le wake my master.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Helpe here, the Ladie Peregrine is dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: If shee be dead, shee wonot make a noyse,
Would al i'th house were dead, we should be at quiet.
Carrie your selfe civillie an i'le send somebody.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: I shall be in for murther, oh my fate!

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Alas my sister, what ha you done, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: I know not the extent of my offence,
But trust me, i le not flie past the next Chamber.
Shew your best charitie, oh my soule is wounded.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Shee returnes, give her more ayre.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Oh my poore sister, welcome to life agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: I know you both, is no bodie else with you?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: No Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Not my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I'le carrie him the newes of her recoverie.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Praie let mee see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Hee's here too soone.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Plo. Cheere up your spirit my Lord, and speake to her,
Shee is alive, and likelie.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: You may come
A litle neerer, if there be no change
In minde, there is in countenance, my Lord,
I have had a short, but pleasing vision,
My thought from a steepe precipice, as you were falling
Into the Sea, an arme chain'd to a Cloud,
Caught hold, and drew you up to Heaven.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: If you dare heare mee speake
Agen, I dare say more, but to your eare.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: I feele a new, and secure confidence.
Will you vouchsafe us favor?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Wee'le not bee
At to much distance.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Can there bee a hope,
After so great a wrong, to finde a mercie?
You must bee more then woman, and you are so.
It was the errour of my soule that drew
The heavie mist upon my eies, they now
See, and admire your innocence, oh Madam,
I have two mightie passions within me;
Two, that are wellcome, yet extreames, a Joy,
To see you live, and sorrow for my trespasse
Against so bright a chastitie, to which,
I kneele within my hart, and aske forgivenesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: If this be earnest, 'tis a heavenlie language.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: I feele a holie flame disperse rich heate,
About me, the corruption of my blood
Is fallen awaie, and of that virtue, which
A divell in mee would have betrayd, I rise
A servant, and admirer, live, oh live,
Thou best of wives, and practise still new wonders
Vpon the hart of lust transformed men,
Vntill time boast, the example of thy faith
Hath purg'd the world, aud taught us how to count
Our howers by thy miracles: I am
In love now with thy goodnesse, by thy selfe
I am, and by some rare, and unknowne act,
Must make a recompence to that faire honour,
I would ha blasted, once againe forgive mee,
And hide the shame, my soule does blush to thinke on.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: This is an noble change, and speaks his nature
Not barren, when good seedes are trusted with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Hee's gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Plo.
SP.L: And did not minde us.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: I am sorie,
I could have chain'd my eares to his discourse,
And willinglie ha growne old to have heard him:
Madam, the Character of praise you gave him,
Is short of that true noblenesse I finde.

SP.SPEAKER: Plo
SP.L: And yet you were not willing to beleeve it.
I thinke I know a man.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: How is this sister?
I hope y'are not in earnest, though hee bee
A Lord, as who can helpe, in my judgement
There are noe mountaines of such noblenesse
As you commend his talke, if he speake not:
Another language to the eare, could never.
Ravish my understanding, though I must
Confesse 'tis wild enough, I doe beginne
To feare you, sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Bee more charitable,
I apprehend your trouble, and shall give you
A faire account of his, and my owne honour,
I could bee merrie now.

SP.SPEAKER: Plo.
SP.L: Here are Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: My customers.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Where is my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Hee's gone, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: I am sure hee has left a hart behind with you,
Most excellent of beauties, in whose trust,
'Tis safer, and more warme, then in his bosome,
Doe you not finde him a brave Gentleman?
He has but one fault Ladie, hee's to modest:
But your discretion must helpe hat.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: I honour him.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Tis well and wiselie done.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Pray tell mee, sir,
I have heard a litle tryall of your wit,
Are you honest too?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Honest too?
I never did suspect your Ladyships
Breeding, and yet this question in publike,
Would stagger the opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: But you having a leading voyce.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: I ha not art to helpe you,
Though I confesse, I might orerule some witts
O'th lower classe, are you honest too?
Besides the freedome of my birth, and wealth
Of blood, I boast no over-swelling fortunes,
As to what purpose, should my witts bee clog'd
With heavie acres, when the Town's Exchequer
Is mine, and every Mercer is my Tenant,
If he pretend to wit, and hope to justifie
His shop-booke, and orthographie of his bills:
I would not have the scandall on my name,
To be cal'd honest, i'th strickt sense I meane,
And as it tyes my blood up, for a Duke-dome:
But you are for my Lord, and I allow it.
How thrive my gallants here?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: They cannot choose
But prosper, sir, and much the better for
Your commendations.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: You may take his opinion Ladie, tis authenticke.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia▪
SP.L: But a litle of your patience: if I found
Within me, that strong appetite to marrie,
Who shall protect me from the statute gentlemen?
If it be fellonie to have two husbands,
I will not marrie above one for certaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Shee s right for that, 'tis dangerous.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Cast lotts.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: And tie my love to chance, forbid discretion.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: Choose whom you love best.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: That's to bee resolu'd
By your demonstration, who loves me best,
For if there be, marke what I tell you, Gentlemen,
But the hundred part of a graine difference,
In your affections, beshrew mee, if
I choose the lightest.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: How's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Wisdome Gentlemen,
And must bee allow'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Let him bee the judge,
Hee knowes us both to a scruple.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Excuse me Gentlemen,
'Tis fit the Ladie satisfie her judgment▪
Although I hate partialitie, it becomes not
I should bee here definitive, to perplexe
The freedome of her choice..

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: What thinke you to agree among our selves?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Sure hee that dares
Doe most for my sake will deserue mee best.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Dee heare that resolution, bee rul'd
I'le open such a path to your ambition—

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: No more.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: At our next visit, you shall know us Ladie,

SP.SPEAKER: Plo.
SP.L: Nay Gentlemen letts to gleeke.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: Commaund us Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Plo.
SP.L: You and my Cozen may
To the same exercise.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: I would bee excused
For some few minuites.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: If it please you Lady,
Weele passe that time at sant: did you not finde
My Character true of those rotten glo-wormes?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: You did a high favor.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: you consult
Your honor in the acknowledgment, I waite you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: When will you open, sir, the booke of destinie
And read the name you talke on? I am confident,
He must be master of an active soule
Whom you preferre, if I mislike his person,
I'le marry his wit, but we loose time, you'le follow.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Methinkes I feele some new accesse of comfort,
Something that tells me, I am neere a blessing,
Or else my poore hart flattets mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: My Lord commanded me present you his best service,
And with it, these: he bad mee say, they are
Prologue to that reward hee hath design'd
Your virtue, I was glad to heare him say so,
And never went more nimblie on his message.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: The mortgage? this confirmes me, he is noble,
A wealthie Carkanet; though I cannot merit
This bountie from him, I am rich in thank's.
But prethee tell me boy, didst not thou bring
Letters, and other Jewells to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: If I remember, you did speake an other
Meaning, then what you now deliver.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: Madam,
Although the narrow tie of dutie bind mee,
To the discharge of his commands, which it
Becomes no servant to dispute, I meete
Honest imployments with more cherefullnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Thou hast a modest countenance, here's to buy the
Garters, and Roses.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: When I goe upon
Lascivious errands, Madam, I take monie,
There is no other benefit belongs to 'em,
But good ones pay themselves, I am rewarded,
I shall have cause to thanke you for my Lord,
If he preserue this temper.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: A good boy: this is not the religion of all Pages.
They are a present worth acceptance,
The piety came with 'em more then doubles
Their value, if vice blush not at rewards,
There is no shame for virtue to receive them▪
But What's all this to me, that am poore still
Without my Peregrine? who all this while
Treads the uneaven path of warre, and danger,
This verie minute, for ought I can tell,
Wounded upon some service, or ingag'd,
To stand the murdring Cannon, oh, my blood
Growes pale within me to imagine, what
Horror attends the Soldier

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Madam, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Ha, my hart trembles.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Sir Walter Peregrine.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Thy lookes speake comfort, what of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Hee is return'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Landed?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Hee's marching up the staires, with another soldade
Tough as his Jerkin, he has a tilting feather,
And lookes soe desperatelie, I feare they have
Brought home two regiments that wonot bee
Casheer'd without a shift.
SP.STAGE: Enter sir Walter Peregrine, and a Captaine.
SP.L: They are here allready.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Oh! let me flie into his armes, my Peregrine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: My best of life!

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Let teares of joy salute thee,
Wellcome, ten thousand wellcomes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: I embrace
Millions of blisse in thee, but let not our
Joy make us unmannerlie, bestow
One welcome on my friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Your pardon, sir,
If after many yeeres of absence, I
Dwell long upon a husbands entertainment,
And if you thinke I have exprest a truth
Of joy to see him, you will easilie
Beleeve the man, whom hee calls friend, is welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Madam, you honour mee, it were a sinne
Not to bee confident.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: And are wee met?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Never I hope to part agen, 'tis time
Wee now should grow together.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: You'le dispence
With mee for some howers, I have friends expect
At my returne a visit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir
SP.L: I shall not
Desire you to let fall no mention
Of mee, the litle stay I purpose here,
You may imagine, carries danger with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: I Hope you know me better.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Noblest friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: I heard some words sound most unkindly from you,
You nam'd a litle stay, have I scarce seene
My happinesse, and must be sad againe
To thinke it will so soone be ravish'd from mee?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Alas my poore Bellamia, I have made
No purchase but of wounds, since my departure.
I have paide some debts of warre, but cannot promise
To cancell one, that threatens mee at home;
What wee have more then to supplie our wants,
Consumes on the Drum head, I was ambitious
To see thee, and this gentleman returning
With expectation to levie men
Gave mee the opportunitie, but I dare
Promise my selfe no dwelling here, scarce owne
My face before a sun-beame, I must walke
I'th darke to all the world but thee, Bellamia:
But trust mee, when my body is cal'd hence
By miserie of my fate, it takes not all
The soule it brought, much stayes to waite on thee:
I know it would afflict thee more, to see mee
A prisoner, chain'd to heavie debts, and shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Thy state is not so lost, and miserable,
As 'tis presented in thy feares, looke here,
And thanke a providence, that smiles upon us,
This is recover'd, wee have some Land
Agen, by whose revenue wee may live,
And expect better fortunes, I have Jewells too,
Bright ones, and rich.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: You have indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Possesse
What I enjoy, and let us live together.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: It cannot, cannot be, alas Bellamia,
How flattring imagination would cozen us,
I am beyond sea still, in my cold Tent,
Where, though my sleeps be broken with the noyse
Of warre, I now securelie dreame of thee,
And of my comming home, and talking to thee,
That thou art rich in land agen and Jewells,
Shadowes, meere shadowes: I am wearie of
This dreame, some charitable cannon wake me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Sir you may trust your eyes, these are no formes, in aerie apprehension, but the truth of things, that call you to be∣leeve, and use them as timelie benefits: yet I may allow you to wonder, there's a story will deserve it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: I know not what I feare, dee thinke 'tis true then?
I will have reason for this faith, pray tell me,
How came you by this wealth, certainelie I left
No summes to purchase these, more my iniustice
To thee, whose plentifull estate I ruin'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: A friend, a noble friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: That died, and gave thee
A swelling legacie, and thou hast made
This use on't to release thy desperate land,
Buy thee a Carkanet, and this proud blaze
Of other Jewells.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: If you please to heare mee,
I must declare, these are the bounty of
A living friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Living?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: A Gentleman—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: A Gentleman? forbeare I am not well.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: One you are bound to honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Tha'st undone me,
Doe not, do not name him,
I know, and feele too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Beleeve me, sir,
My storie's full of innocence, and when
You have more knowledge of this friend, you'le quit
Your feares, and call him to your hart.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: My hart▪
Is very busie, yet you may tell mee
His name, to whose strange bounty I am so oblig'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: More to his virtue, though his title
Carrie the shine of honor, he has a soule
More glorious; have patience but to heare mee,
You will confesse it, and reward his pietie
With praise above a man, and be in love
With him your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: In Love—

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: The Lord Fitzavarice.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Ha? the wanton Lord Fitzavarice.
Thou most undone of women, did my absence
So forfit me, or ebbe of wealth corrupt
Thy giddie soule, thou couldst imagine, I
Would thanke thy lust to peece up my wild ruines?
Transforme mee gentle Heaven,
For if I be a man, and hold the knowledge
Of this dishonour, I shall doe an act
Equall to this, and murder this false woman.
Have I thought life not tedious for thy sake,
And in my povertie summ'd up wealth enough
But in my hopes to see thee, were my winters
Not cold, when I but thought I had Bellamia,
Were all the toyles, and troubles of my spring,
Not valued for this harvest? curse upon
Thy Salarie, were it a price to buy
All Kingdoms, that the Sunne e're shed a beame on,
Earn'd from thy bodies infamie, I'de choose
To live i'th galley first, and chain'd to'th oare,
Give up my breath through torture. I'le to prison,
And wellcome all the stings, that want of libertie,
Disease, and famine, can let fall upon mee,
And call thee yet more killing then all they,
Till my hard Creditors forgive mee in pitty,
And curse thee into all I have suffer'd,
Wives shall accuse thy periurie, whose act
Is able to make all the truth suspected,
And Virgins frighted at thy name, resolve
Never to marrie, while the race of men
Curse thee, for whom they nere shall spring agen.
But I let passion foole mee, and my tamenesse
May prompt thee to more sinne, I'le bee reveng'd;
But first on him, that grafted shame upon mee:
It shall bee thy first punishment, to see
Him bleeding, where is he? come what fine conveiances
To keepe your Goate close, till time play the baud,
And secure all your ruttings? I must finde him,
Appeare then staine to honor, Lordly divell:
Where art? Fitzavarice? Fitzavarice!
Whose reeking squire are you sir, ha my Lords?
Shew mee strait where this Fox doth Earth himselfe,
Or I'le—

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: I know not where my Lord is, but ther's one a Bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: A Bed, expecting her, where?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: But hee's asleepe, you'le wake him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Shew mee villaine quicklie.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Oh, this way, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Has miserie a name beyond my suffering?
Hath love, and fortune both conspir'd to drop
Their stings into my bosome?

SP.SPEAKER: Within.
SP.L: Helpe Dormant.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Sir Solitary in his shirt persued by Sir Walter.

SP.SPEAKER: Plo.
SP.L: A plott, a plott to murther me, hold, what art?
My Nephew; ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: 'Tis not he, Uncle you must
Excuse my complement, he shall not flie mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Plo.
SP.L: Who goes about to flie? he did not wound mee,
A naked man is soone undone, 'tis wisedome
To sleepe hereafter in a shirt of Maile,
When came he hither, from the nether-lands?
Hee is sent upon some murdring designe;
But why with his sword drawne, why not a knife?
Some great man is in danger; ha! my Neece weeping,
I'le sift her, Bellamia?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel
SP.L: Oh my husband, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Nay, then there is a plott, whom would he kill?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: The Lord Fitzavarice.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: I knew it was some great man mus be visited
Beneath the ribbs, men of such vast estates
Are not long lived.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: I know not what to do, sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Hee's i'th conspiracy, reveale the plott to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: My fellow Oldrat mett him, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Ha, more traitors.
I did suspect that fooles simplicity,
What man is to be trusted? if these men
Thrive in their first attempt, the stat's in danger.
This Oldrat is a politician.
I'le stand upon my guard, entrench, and dare
The Ghost of Tilly.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: 'Tis not verie warme, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Your cold considerations are best.
But I'le to bed agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: They are here, oh!

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Sir Walter, Bell: and Oldrat.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Away.
Shall wee bee never free from plotts?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. Wal.
SP.L: Has he beene gone this hower sayst?

SP.SPEAKER: Old.
SP.L: Yes, and please your worship,
Would I were well gon too.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Yet will you heare me, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: And trust the language of your teares? they're false,
Your gamester shall weepe blood: here we untwist
Our harts, set up o'th trade, the youth will joyne.
Thou maiest be still Bellamia, but not mine.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus Quartus.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Sir Walter, and Captaine, as comming from a Taverne.

SP.SPEAKER: Within.
SP.L: All's paid, and yee are welcome gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: So; so, this Taverne was well thought upon:
In my opinion, 'tis a great deale better
Then to have trusted your owne passion
In such a cause, which easilie might engage you
To danger, when your rage grew high, and loud.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: I have obey'd your counsell: you wil carry this?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: I have promis'd you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: And yet you must acknowledge
The wrong is greater then to bee contain'd
Within this narrow leafe, and till I have
Reveng'd, it swells each minute to a volume.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: My Lord is noble this way, and be confident,
Will render you an account, worthie his person,
Though I am sorry to salute him first,
With a defiance.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Sha't not for all the World
Doe thy selfe preiudice in his favor, i'le
Disengage thee agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Now you dishonor me, though he has bin pleas'd
To use mee nobly when we met at Bergen,
That must not barre the office of a gentleman
To his friend: he has been a Soldier himselfe,
And must grant this an act of my profession.
You are certaine he has done the injurie?
For 't is not safe to trust suspition,
In things of this high nature; Life and Honor
Must not bee question'd upon naked feares,
And windie suppositions, pardon mee
This plainenesse, you imagine I dare fight.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Shall I beleeve 'tis day, when I behold
The Sunne disperse his beames about the World?
Doe I know cold, or heate, or when I thirst?
Shall I be confident we talke together?
My cause will aske the same degree of faith,
As built on equall certainty.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: I urge it
No father:
Is not that hee?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: 'Tis the same.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: With-draw, be carefull of your selfe, I'le meete you
At your Uncles house, and give you an account
Of this imployment.

SP.SPEAKER: Pag.
SP.L: Shee is an excellent woman,
If't be no wrong to her goodnesse that I spend
My childish character.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Th'art right, she is
Indeed boy, and shews fairer for that goodnesse,
I have done nothing yet to cherish her
Rare pietie, or to deserue my pardon.
I'le studie both.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: My Lord, an humble servant—

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Captaine you honour mee,
Welcome to England, how doe all our friends
I'th low-Countries?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Happie in being your servants,

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: When Landed you?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: But this morning, I am fortunate
In this opportunitie, my Lord, to speake with you,
And to present—

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Some letters, you oblige me,
How does sir Walter Peregrine?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Well,
If please you command your boy more distance:
This paper comes from him. My Lord, I should
Be guiltie of much sinne to your owne honour,
Not to assure my selfe noble construction
From you, I had no thought within this hower,
To have brought more then my humble service
To your Lordship, which shall still be fairelie yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Pag.
SP.L: I doe not like this soldads Embassage:
A challenge! some young Gentlemen that have
Strong purses and faint soules, do use to fine for't,
As Citizens doe for Sheriffes: the Towne swash-Bucklers
Practise these feates, and live by't; but my Lord
Hath beaten that opinion out of some,
It should appeare, all are not yet converted.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: How's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: He appeares noble, and not mou'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Are you acquainted with his discontents?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: He has imparted some, but I have no
Commission to expostulate.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: I thanke you,
You shew your selfe a Gentleman, and his friend.
He shall heare from me, I had ambition
To enjoy you longer: but the termes of honour
Threaten on both sides, know me for your servant.
Pray heaven he injure not the innocent Lady.
He has directed where to send to him,
And so againe I thanke you noble Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Your Lordships honorer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: This came unlook'd for, but I must not wave it,
O'th sodaine whom shall I employ? I cannot
Want friends ambitious of these engagements:
The next I meet.

SP.SPEAKER: Confident?
SP.L: Hee has profest his soule was mine,
I'le trie him for his body in this action.
Yet he that is not honest, dares not fight sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: My honorable Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Oh Master Confident,
Your hopes thrive in your mistresse?

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: Your Lordship
Was pleas'd to advance 'em, she affects my wit,
And bold discourse, I turne and winde her soule,
Shee loves mee infinitelie.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: I hope not, harke.
Be not too forward, I'me acquainted with
Her disposition, doe not flatter her,
Nor seeme to dote, shee'le triumph then: if you
Would make all sure, be rul'd by me, and slight her,
And shee will court you, 'tis the tricke of Ladies,
If you abuse her, 'twere not much amisse.
I would not have the wench undoe her selfe
Vpon this fellow. I advise the best
And speediest way, for I expect your promise,
When she is yours, to bring us more acquainted.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Be confident my Lord, good manners will
Instruct me to allow you the first fruits,
It was the fashion of our northerne Princes:
And challenge it from your poore Homager.
I shall be as warme the first night with her Land,
And monie's. Then it seemes you have no hope
To spring her sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Since our last salute,
Icicles hang upon my lippe.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: My wife, for I
Dare speake her so, with smiles shall chase
That winter▪ and shoot spring throughout your blood;
You shall not only from her lippe tast Cherries,
But she shall plant 'em with her amorous kisse
Vpon your owne, and they shall grow from thence
To tempt the Queene of Love to Adonis garden:
It shall bee happinesse enough for me, to watch
The Hesperides, but in no Dragons shape,
That you may rifle with securitie
The golden Orchard, I shall boast enough
By having an Elysium to serue you;
Her eyes are wealth enough to me, above
A rocke of Diamonds, her breath rich gummes
Sweeter then those the Phenix makes her Altar,
When she is her owne sacrifice, and fannes
The glowing Pile with her gray wings; her voyce
Enough for me, whose harmonie would build
Vp Thaebes agen, and make it after move,
And follow her; one touch of her soft palme
Is health enough to me, and were I old
As Eson, would restore my active nerves,
And state my youth at thirtie: I can gather
Warme Snow from her faire brow, her chin, her neck,
And at my eyes drinke enough immortalitie:
Sated with these, I'le finde new appetite,
And come a wanton strawberying to her cheekes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: No more, you have exprest in this your faith
To me, which I am bound in honour to
Acknowledge, and without more study, have
A fit occasion to requite, and shew
How neare I place your love, there is a difference
Betweene another gentleman, and my selfe,
Growne to a challenge, I must answer it,
You that are so well read in bookes, cannot
Be ignorant of man, I'le trust my life
And honor with no second, but your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: My Lord I see you know me, and am blest
The chosen man to serue you, from a troupe
Of lives at your command, I should have envied
His fate, on whom else you had throwne this honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Soresolute? you have not seene sir Walter Peregrine,
Hee's return'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: I heare some whisper—

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: I have nam'd my enemie, the defyance comes from him.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: Hee's jealous of his wife, good gentleman,
And wod be a cuckold upon record.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Call on mee
An hower hence, I'le be at home, and use
Your friendship for the burden of an answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: I shall thinke Time hath lost his wings till then.
He put me to it cunninglie, but his
Discoverie releev'd me, though I make
A noyse i'th Towne, and am admir'd for bouncing,
I am coole enough i'th dogge-days: my Lords Scrivener.
Fortune presents him to my with, the man
Of all World most usefull to my purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Scr.
SP.L: Master Confident, Rapture your most humble servant—

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: When saw you the squires Vayne-man, and Pumicestone?

SP.SPEAKER: Scr.
SP.L: Not since I procur'd 'em a thousand pound,

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: Now you put me in minde of debts, has not
Sir Walter Peregrine a name within
Some list of yours? has he no creditors
By your acquaintance?

SP.SPEAKER: Scr.
SP.L: I beseech you doe not
Vex me with his remembrance. I have pai'd
Some monies for him, he has other friends
That would be glad to embrace him.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: Sure hee would not
Be such a traytor not to secure thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Scr.
SP.L: Would I could reach him.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: Why hee is return'd,
Within this foure and twentie howers, you may
Salute him too. Alas, a summe may bee
The ruine of thy fortunes, could he have
So litle charitie?

SP.SPEAKER: Scr.
SP.L: I would shew
As much to him, if I could set my phangs on him.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: I have ever wish'd thee well, and if thou darst
Be secret, I'le direct thee to recover him,
I cannot say the deb't; may be, the Knight
Is poore still.

SP.SPEAKER: Scr
SP.L: Hang him, Master Confident,
It will refresh my hart to be reveng'd;
Some say mens blood, I say their bones are sweetest.
I'de make him an example, I'le not tell
My shirt on't, how honest Master Confident?

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: Fate dotes upon thee, he, the very hee,
Be art-full, j'le salute him, and delaie
His pace with some discourse, whilst you
Fetch shoulder-clappers, noble Sir Walter Peregrine,
I feele a spring-tide in my hart of joy,
Swell to congratulate your safe returne,
The Towne has droup'd for your societie.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: You are still the eligant time wit, I am happy
To witnesse both your braine, and body florish.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: What news abroad? all expectation
Is fixt upon this summers warre, wee breath
Nothing but German aire, allthough the chance
Of warre be uncertaine, you can tell which hand
Is fortunate, how ha the Dice runne hitherto?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Ther's not much wonne, or lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: No Townes of note
Taken? no convoyes of provision
Cut off?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Sir you are inquisitive, as if
You would turne Gallobelgicus, I am
On some affaires now, that importune their
Dispatch, my stay being short I must attend them.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Nay prethee Knight be courteous, 'tis an age
Since we converst, i'st true what lou'd fame scatters
Of the great Generalls revolt?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Wee have
But the relation.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: He is slaine for certaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: There was an execution.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: And what treasure
Was taken by the enemy? they talke
Of Millions.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Enough to keepe the Eagle
In a good diet. I beseech you pardon me,
We shall hereafter meete, and ha more freedome
To enlarge our selves, & when you have my particulars,
I will be bold to inquire in the Exchange
Your newes at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: I obserue trouble in you,
I hope y'are in no danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: If you'le give mee
The liberty of a subject, and allow me
The Kings high way, I shall have lesse suspition,
You wonot pay my debts.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: I beg your pardon,
Pray doe not wound my service to you with
A jealous thought, I wonot for the World
Engage you another minute.
Now for the blood-hounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Off.
SP.L: Sir, we arrest you

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Is the mischiefe falne?

SP.SPEAKER: Off
SP.L: Your sword shall keepe the peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Scr.
SP.L: 'Tis at my suite.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Thyne?

SP.SPEAKER: Scr.
SP.L: I doe but lead the dance to twenty more.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Heare me, what's your demaund? let me not goe
To prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Scr,
SP.L: An action of a thousand pound more,
For the Lord Fitzavarice.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Ha? then I am betray'd, that Lord's a villaine,
That I could reach his hart; release my body
But for two howers, my soule be forfeited
For ever, if I render not my selfe
Your honest Prisoner.

SP.SPEAKER: Scr.
SP.L: That were a pretty jest.
Looke to your charge.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: Here is a duell taken up discreetlie.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Blacke Jew, base Lord, dam'd villaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Scr.
SP.L: They can tame you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Why looke you gentlemen, I'le not puzzle you
To finde out dangers, famine, fire, and sword,
Or desperate things.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: Trifles for thy sweet sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Ps.
SP.L: I would not wish you, upon easie termes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: To prevent these, I have thought a way my selfe,
And with lesse cost, to try you, I have made
A vow I wonot marrie these six monthes,
During which time, if you dare for my sake
Visit me every day, and never speake to me,
Nor in my company to any other—

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: How Lady?
Shall I not answer any gentleman
Or Lady, that shall put a question to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: By no meanes.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: You will give me leave to answer you,
If you should aske me any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Not a syllable,
Though I desir'd to know what a clocke 'tis,
Ther's your obeydience, at six monthes end
I may reward your silence.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Shee'le make him the dumbe Knight.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: I wonot engage you to be a mute
So long, you shall be allow'd to speake, and see me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: You are noble Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: But with this condition,
That whatsoever I entreate you say
Or doe, you put in act the contrary
The very contrary, you understand mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: How's this? if you command me to affect you,
What can I doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: I wonot bee so cruell.
If these conditions please, you may proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: But harke you Lady, I may laugh before you,
And in your absence have the libertie
To use my tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: What else, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: And when must I beginne to mumme.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: I'le tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Another word,
If we be just to your commands, deere Lady,
At six months end, how shall we both be satisfied?
You have forgot the statute.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Hee that shall
Expresse most care to doe his penance for mee,
Must be the man, I say no more, imagine.
My Lord Fizavarice.
Now beginn's your triall.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: How fares your vertuous sister Ladie Peregrine?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: That Gentleman can tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: He tell me?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Yes, he had a message to deliver you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Sir you much honour me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Nay, let him know't, here have beene turnes my Lord,
Since you were here.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Is shee in health; you doe not mocke mee?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: If you love me, tell him the whole storie, prethee,
For my sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: How shee Jeeres him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Pox on your subtill shoulders, are you drunke?
If I shall thinke you Jeere me, be still silent,
I'le make you speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Ha, ha.

DIV2.STAGE: Hee kickes him, Vaine. Exit shaking his head, and shoulders.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: What doe you laugh at?

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: At his follie my noble Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: 'Tis well you doe, sir, what's your meaning Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: You shall know presentlie, if you intreate
That Gentleman to stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: He is not going.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: But your commands upon him will make sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Let me intreate you not to leave me, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: I leave you my noble Lord? if everie sand
Within my glasse, were a long life, I should
Emploie 'em all in waiting on your Lordship.
And thinke the time were poore, and short to serve you
I leave you my good Lord? i'me not about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Pray, sir, staie.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Your Lordships humble servant, some affaires
Presse my departure.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: You'le not mocke me, sir?
