SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: You shall stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Ladie I am gone, my Lord, I must beseech
Your pardon, for the world, I dare not slippe
A minute:

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Then go, you may go.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Not for a Kingdome Lady, I will stay,
And grow here for your service.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: How came these gentlemen by these strange humors?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: I'le tell you, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Sir Solitary Plott, your husband and my worthy Lord and Master, commends his service to your Lordship, and praies you would please to accommodate him, with your Coach.

SP.SPEAKER: Plo.
SP.L: This fellow's infected too with serious follie.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Towards midnight hee does purpose to take the aire,
And make some visites.

SP.SPEAKER: Plo.
SP.L: Visites and aire at midnight? pray returne
My Lord imbassador to sir Solitary,
I will give order when I goe to Bed,
To have the Coach made ready for his progresse.
Stay, I have a great desire to see his worship,
Has he the same complexion still? I prethee
Leave of thy gravitie, and answer me,
Is he in Bed?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: No Madam, a most strange
Disaster broke his sleepe, and we shall be
At counsell presentlie, do not I talke
Allready like a states-man?

SP.SPEAKER: Plo.
SP.L: It shall be so, come neerer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: This your device: tis pleasant and persue it,
Your sister—

SP.SPEAKER: Plo.
SP.L: Bee you sure, and secure, Jacintha you must
with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Whether?

SP.SPEAKER: Plo.
SP.L: To my husbands Chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Madam, your husband is return'd I heare.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: I hope you have not met.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Why noble Madam?
SP.STAGE: Enter Vaine-man as peeping if my Lord were gone, and beckons to Pumicestone.
SP.L: Wee shall be friends if you have mercie, to
Forgive what's past, my soule shall not deserue
His ill opinion, I hope all is well betweene you two.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: No harts did ever meete
More loving lie, untill he saw—

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: What, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: The presents that you sent me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: It was my feare.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: My dumbe Knight too, we shall have the more mirth.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Would I had beene poore still, although you bring
All innocent thoughts. My Lord, I must beseech you,
Never to see me agen, oh never, sir,
It will be dangerous to expresse your virtue,
And every minute you staie here, is fatall,
Alas I feare hee's come.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: My Lord, I have beene active,
And all my bodies in a bath to finde you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir
SP.L: Walter Peregrine is arrested.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Oh miserie of miseries!

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Looke to your mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: Her Ladiships pardon, I obseru'd not her
So neere. 'tis verie certaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: I suspect
This knave, alas poore gentleman, and yet
Tis no mis-fortune to me, things considered:
Now he is safe, and I may walke securelie;
In Prison let him lie and coole his valour.
I shall bee in charitie with the tribe of varletts,
For this good turne, this taking him i'th nick,
And owe the wretch a summe, for being so fortunate
To set the Mastives on him, I owe thee too,
For thy good newes, come Confident.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: To my ambition.
Dee heare my Lord, the good newes is not all
You owe me for, I knew it would be gratefull;
You owe me for the act, it was my wit
Betri'd him to the arrest, held him in prate
Whilst the honest Knave your Scrivener fetch'd the vultures
With phangs keene as the Divells.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: How am bound to thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: I knew t'was necessarie. Every man
That vowes his service, has not that extent
Of braine to bring about these fine things for you.
What thinke you of the mamoseile, his wife now?
You have no opportunitie, no power
To humble her proud bodie, while her husband
Setts up a friperie with his gaie wardrobe;
Grows into new acquaintance with diseases,
And comfortable vermine; breakes stone walls
To shew the proverbe, and his hunger mightie;
Curses his Starrs, and learnes to cant, and praise
The steame of ale, with an unchristian tost in't;
Doth reverence Barmudas, and the ghost
Of cheese, with the Egyptian Idoll Onyous,
And crusts to breake an Elephants tooth. All this
I ha done for you, my good Lord,

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: For which
I must pronounce thee a rascall; sordid wretch,
Was this your act for me? curse on thy soule for't,
My honor bleeds to death, see me no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Scr.
SP.L: My Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: You are come in a good time, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: Are you so cunning my yong Lord, I must make my Ladie
Sure, ere hee talke, and tell her this; 'tis not'
The constitution of everie Lord
To take unkindlie when a man compounds
A duell for him, if I bee driven too't
I can forswear't agen. Let valiant fooles
Brag of their soules no matter what they say,
A coward dares in ill, do more then they.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Sir Walter Peregrine, Captaine, and under-Sheriffe.

SP.SPEAKER: She.
SP.L: Tis all the favor I could shew him, sir,
To make my house his Prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Tis but hell, one storie higher.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: You must arme your selfe
With noble fortitude, passion but unmans us,
And makes us lesse for bearing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Dost thinke friend,
The sense of all my debts could shake me thus?
I knew 'twould come, and in my feares examined
The mischiefe they present, 'tis not their weight
Affrights me, let the vultures whet their Tallons,
And creditors, with harts more stubborne, then
The mettle they adore, double their malice,
Had I a pile of debts upon me, more
Heavie then all the World, it could, but with
The pressure keepe this peece of earth beneath 'em,
My soule would be at large, and feele no burden;
That which I count my torture, exceeds all
That yet has beene in mention. At a time,
Almost the verie minute, when my hopes
Were ripe to punish him, and revenge had mounted
Her steelie arme whose fall had crush'd the soule
Of my fames ravisher, to be snatched up
By a wirle-wind thus, disarm'd of all my hopes,
My hands bound up, not able to releeve
My bleeding honour: this, this murders mee.
And that all this should be his cursed plott,
That gave me my first wound.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Dee thinke my Lord
Can shew himselfe so dishonorable?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Can Lords
Be cowards? dost not appeare, when I am persued
By his owne blood-hounds? has he not laid on mee
(And what may not by this example follow
To sinke me to a dungeon) all the debts
I owe him? nay is it not cleere, hee practises
Intelligence abroad, provoking others
To lay their summes upon me, that I may
Consume a Prisoner, and assure his lust
More scope to revell with my adulterous Madam,
My wife whose name is torment to my hart,
Bove all the engines ment to wound mankinde▪
Oh woman, that hast forfeited the glorie▪
Of thy creation, and become mans ruine.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: This is a circumstance I confesse, but yet
Cannot make me conclude my Lord so ignoble:
I know he had a wanton pile of flesh,
But a more noble soule, then to betraie
His enemie so baselie.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Ist not mischife
Enough to feele the crueltie of a prisoner,
But that black fiend must presecute my eye-sight
Th'adopted sonne of Lucifer?

SP.SPEAKER: Scr.
SP.L: I have a letter from a noble friend of yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Carry it to hell.

SP.SPEAKER: She.
SP.L: Correct your passion,
And leave your understanding free, to know
Your happinesse, this man how e're your rage
Let flie at him, will deserue better Character,
When he appeares the meanes of your enlargment.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: How Master Sheriffe?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: He meanes of my enlargment?
Take heede how you do mocke me, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: She.
SP.L: Your Sword—
Y'are free agen, each particle of a deb't discharg'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: By whom?

SP.SPEAKER: She.
SP.L: Not a fee left unsatisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: I am in a Wildernesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Scr.
SP.L: You may come out when you please, if your worship
Will be at leasure to peruse this paper,
There is his name, hath beene at all this charge,
Who has commanded me to aske your pardon,
And on my knees I begge it, I am undone else,
For ever with his Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. Cap.
SP.L: Lord Fitzavarice?

SP.SPEAKER: Scr.
SP.L: It was without his knowledge, Master Confident
Charm'd me into it, the divell did assist.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: The divell?

SP.SPEAKER: Scr.
SP.L: Yes, we three, I am sorrie for it,
And if your worship have occasion
To use a hundred peeces more, I have'em
Readie at your service, pray entreat him to
Accept it, I expect no scribling for it,
Nor use, nor principall, nor his word; but to
My Lord, that I may be the driver still of all his monies.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: I was confident, and long since cleer'd his Lordship
In my thoughts.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Was there ever such a thing in nature?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: You must take the mans benevolence,
He is undone else, come there is no harme in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Scr.
SP.L: If they be not weight, I'le change 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: No, no.

SP.SPEAKER: Scr.
SP.L: I humblie thanke your worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: I am all wonder.
SP.STAGE: Reades, When you finde all things fairely discharged, though you ac∣quit not me, be pleased to continue a voluntary Prisoner for some few minutes, there is necessity we should discourse, and conclude something else for both our honours.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: You must pronounce him innocent, had he
Beene coward, as you thought him, at lese charge
He might ha sau'd his honor, and secur'd your absence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: I beginne to be a sham'd,
And my suspition cowardlie falls off;
Yet certainelie all this proceeds not from
Devotion to me, it is a bountie
He lookes my wife should thanke him for, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Now I see all are your emptie jealousies,
But thinke and be convinc'd, were his thoughts foule
As you imagine to your Lady, it
Had beene ridiculous to set you at libertie,
The only barre to his designe, lust is not
So tame, and foolish, common policie
would have instructed him to have let you rather
Languish, and rot in Prison, be collected,
And thinke whom your false feares have injur'd,
A noble wife and friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: I am too blame,
This act hath made me understand two soules.
I'le take 'em both to mine, and aske forgivenesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Your Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Forgive me my Bellamia,
Thou appearst white agen, and only I
Blacke with my false suspitions of thy goodnesse,
My Lord has given me a satisfaction
Large as his virtue, welcome to my bosome,
My best, my chast Bellamia.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: This is joy
Able to drowne my poore hart, but is all
This peace concluded?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Thus agen confirm'd.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Iust heaven hath heard my prayers, happy Bellamia.
What riches I embrace, what worlds of treasures,
In every kisse, how manie lives I take
From those sweet smiles?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Who could suspect this Ladie?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: But I am lost agen, in what place am I?
I'st not a Prison? oh that sad thought shoots
A trembling through me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: All is cur'd agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Bellamia
SP.L: I am free too, out of debt,
Nay I did wonder at it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: You amaze me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Wast not a brave Physitian, that could cure
Two such distempers, when my soule, and fortune
Lay gasping, to recover both? 'tis done,
Done by thy friend, and mine, that honest Lord
Hath paid all, to the scruple of a fee,
What thanks shall we both pay him my Bellamia?
Can he hath done this miracle, allow
A place for lust within him? 'tis impossible.
But he is comming hither, stay not thou,
It will require more leasure to expresse
Thy gratitude, returne, and tell thy friends
The wonder first, that when I shall present
His person next, they may have spacious soules,
To admire and entertaine him.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: I obey you,
Doe not allay this unexpected joy
With a sad change good heaven.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: You will expect him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Religiously, an age I'le wait for him,
I prethee stay, and witnesse with what cheerfulnesse
I'le aske his pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: He is come.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: My Lord,
As you have made me object of your mercy,
By such an act of bounty, as noe times
Have gloried in, and in that showne the cleerenesse
Of your braue soule, uncapable of staine,
Still let it shine with charity, and make
Mee confident of pardon, for an injurie
I blush, and dare bleede for, to shew repentance.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Are you then satisfied?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: I am my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: I was bold, but with no purpose to disparage
Your credit, to discharge some trifling debts.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: They were great, my Lord, and must enlarge my ac∣knowledgment,
you have oblig'd two lives to pray for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: And the whole age to admire.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: You would encourage mee.
One word, your honor's safe agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: And happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Mine suffers, 'tis but yong and growing on me,
It bleeds by your suspition, I was bound
To this expence, 'tis a malicious World,
And men are apt to imagine, I was glad
You were in prison, to preserue my skinne
with some excuse, this brand must not come neere
My forehead, though your sea be calme, I would not
Have my fame lost i'th tempest of mens tongues,
I have made no reply, in point of man,
To your challenge, and the noyse may be dispers'd,
Nor will what you are pleas'd to accept, render
Me lesse unquestioned, but beget mens feares
At a high rate I have brib'd your patience
Baselie, perhaps, their impudence will reach
To say, I have bought my passage to your Ladie,
And your consent to'th shame,

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: I will proclaime you
Noble to all the World, and my preserver.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Ther's nothing but your sword can doe me right,
We shall not trouble seconds, if you please
The Captaine stand for both, he is a gentleman
Knowne trulie valiant, which implyes he cannot
Deceive where he is trusted, I'le expect,
You'le follow as you are a Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: He seemes troubled. What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Didst thinke it possible so faire a Skie
Should be deliver'd of a tempest?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: I'le tell thee as we walke, thou must not leave us.
That man is miserablie compel'd, that must,
To save his fame, be to himselfe unjust.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus Quintus.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Sir Solitarie, Dormant, and Oldrat.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: The Coach will be made readie.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: So, so, lett's thinke and talke of something else:
Tim's precious, lett's talke wiselie, 'twill concerne us,
My braine is not in tune about my nephew,
Who knowes upon what plott he is sent hither,
The Duch are grand projectors, letts examine
Where he is gon now.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: My opinion is, to kill some body, or other.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: That would be knowne, and yet I heard a buzze,
Some noble Man was aim'd at, we were best
Say nothing, and discover him to the state,
We may be else in danger, and made accessaries
To the parricide, which is not as the vulgar
Interpret, killing of a father, but
Parem cedendo, killing of a Peere,
A Peere o'th land, marke that.

SP.SPEAKER: Old.
SP.L: I understand a Procedendo
Well enough, but who shall serue the writ?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Vnder your pardon, how can
You prove he is a murderer, let him first kill
Some bodie, no matter who it be, and then you may
Discover him with a safe conscience.

SP.SPEAKER: Old.
SP.L: Laughs.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: What's the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Old.
SP.L: I am of an opinion under correction that if wee
Should discover him, wee should not carrie it so
Privatelie, but it would be knowne, and then we shall
Be in as much danger o'th tother side for concealing it.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Laughs—

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Who's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Now I thinke better on't, it cannot be conceal'd
Vnder your favour fellow Oldrat, for if we do not
Discover, the state will not be so wise, as we are,
And then 'twere pitie o'their lives, besids
If he go on to kill whom he list, and no bodie heare on't
He may undoe the Towne by degrees in a moment,
And neither we nor any that is hurt, the wiser for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Old.
SP.L: Laughs agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Who is it laughs?

SP.SPEAKER: Old.
SP.L: Not I, sir, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Nor I, sir, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Stand both before me, is there not some spirit
I'th roome? has not some conjurer a plot upon me?
Cato was wise, and never laugh'd, but when
Out of his casement, he beheld an Asse
Eate Thistles, wher's the may-game? will none answer?
Sure they did laugh at me, but I'le prevent 'em,
And vex their spleenes, away. I wonot trust
A laughing visard, ther's a killing face
Behind it, oh the juggling of the World!
Am I ridiculous at home? there is
Some plot in agitation. I smell a Rat.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: If please you, sir, there is a dumbe Embassador desires to
Speake with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: A dumbe Embassador?
When does he looke for audience? of what nation?
Where in the Map is dumbe-land? I should much
Affect that Countrie, let him have accesse.
I understand you are a dumbe Embassador;
Your businesse pray with me: you are no Lawyer,
Nor no divine I take it, are there no women
Non Magpies in your Countrie?

DIV2.STAGE: Vaineman makes signes, and salutes him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: This fellow must have a rare understanding,
For nature recompenseth the defects
Of one part, with redoundance in another:
Blind men have excellent memories, and the tongue
Thus indispos'd, ther's treasure in the intellect:
Yet there may be a plott, hee's sent to obserue mee,
A state spie, but I'le cozen his intelligence,
And be as dumbe as he.

DIV2.STAGE: They make signes one to another.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: What are you, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: I am his interpreter.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Oh then first answer me, how came he dumbe?

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: With me lancholie, sir, he has a strange
Humor to crosse the methode of the World.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: As how, sir? pray be plaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Why; sir, to make
The night his time for study, talke, or businesse,
And never go to bed but in the morning.
But keepe this to your selfe, for 'tis a secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Study? what did he study praie o'th nights?

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Why plotts, nothing but plotts: he did suspect
All mankinde, nay their shadowes in the hangings,
If they but laid their heads together, were
Dangerous, and talk'd treason, such a foole,
A serious foole was never before extant.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: How does my Solitary Uncle?

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Ha Cozen, forbeare, we are engag'd upon
Affaires of weight, that's an Embassador.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: What language does he speake?

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: None, none; but this is his interpreter.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Interpreter, and yet he speaks no language.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Hee'le over-heare you, 'tis a dumbe Embassador.
I pray be gone, you are a woman, goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: And can you get no other company
Then dumbe and mad-folkes?

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Who is mad?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: That Gentleman.
Be you but master of some sense a while,
I'le mak't appeare he has none. Come forward, sir,
Doe you obserue his motion? I intreate
He should come forward, and he plaies the crab.
Stand still, sir, I beseech you.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: With your pardon
I must be in action, it does stirre my blood,
Which would congeale through cold else in my veins.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: If it be beneficiall to your body
Practise this motion still.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: 'Tis very strange;
He now appeares a statue:
Are they not both mad? doe you thinke Jacintha
They have no plott in this, how came they thus distracted?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: This grew mad with catching cold
A bed, and lying from his wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Cold causes are very dangerous.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: You are somthing guilty on't.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Pl.
SP.L: What if my husband be asleepe?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Wee'le wake him.

SP.SPEAKER: Old
SP.P: Good Madam be not troublesome, doe not you know who I am? I charge you to resist us, come your waies, where; where be these traitors? let me see, where is sir Solitary? I thought he would ha shewne more wit then to concele traitors in his house.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.L: Traitors?

SP.SPEAKER: Old.
SP.L: Traitors, we looke for, and traitors we will have,
And they be above ground.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: I saw two suspitious persons come into the house with my
Owne eyes, and they must out, there they are, I'le take
My oath Master Constable.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Master Vaineman, and Master Pumicestone you two suspected
For traitors, oh the rotten harts of men!

SP.SPEAKER: Old.
SP.P: Reprehend them. Your good Knight must goe too, goe cheerfully 'twill be the better for you, if you discharge an honest conscience, you may have the favor to hang tell you be dead.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: Did ever any man was sure o'th gallowes, shake so?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: This fright may worke some good effect upon him,
Many men have beene frighted from their witts,
Having none left, why ist not possible
He should be frighted backe againe into 'em?

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: One word I beseech you, 'tis time to speake.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Pl.
SP.L: I hope you did not meane this for his cure,
I am not so wearie cozen of my freedome.
He that's full master of his reason, may
Be master of his wife too, which I like not.

SP.SPEAKER: Per.
SP.L: My Uncle, sister, Madam. Sir Ha more plotts?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: What's the news sister? you looke pleasantlie.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Your face is full of sunshine Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Per.
SP.L: blesse me, but what are these?

SP.SPEAKER: Old.
SP.L: We are subjects of command, shee'l discover us.

SP.SPEAKER: Per.
SP.L: Men? apprehended? what new feares invade me?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: What shall we doe now?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: E'en what you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Per,
SP.L: Why this is Dormant your servant Uncle.

SP.SPEAKER: Old.
SP.L: Who would ha thought it?

SP.SPEAKER: Per.
SP.L: And your name Oldrat, what's the matter gentlemen?
Ha you an interlude?

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: If they be no officers, we can be no traitors.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Twas Mistris Jacintahs plott, we did but act it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: I was desirous of a scene of mirth,
How farre wee should ha driven it, I know not,
Just so ridiculous are all your plotts Uncle, ha, ha.
You had your parts my brace of learned gentlemen,
Whom I doe discharge from feare and further penance.

SP.SPEAKER: Per.
SP.L: Make not your selfe the generall derision,
Your drudges mirth.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Pl.
SP.L: Nay, let him have his humour.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: If you have still ambition to be laught at,
And thinke it possible I can love such motleyes,
Come thus a wooing every day, I shall finde
Some tricke at last to make your worships famous.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: What thinke you o'this?

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.P: One of us is sure to carry her, what thinke you o'th de∣vice, and the worst come to the worst, for the thousand pound?

SP.SPEAKER: Va,
SP.L: We must agree, pay it, and be reveng'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Pu.
SP.L: Doe not you thinke you have undone us now,
And that we shall dispaire, and drowne our selves,
Or slippe out of the World in a cleane halter?
No, we will live to vex thee, for my part
Because thou gavest me liberty to speake,
To shew I scorne to obey thee, and in malice
To thy injunction, I will never speake
Agen, to any woman, in revenge,
I'le be more dumbe then he was.

SP.SPEAKER: Va.
SP.L: And because.
Thou didst injoyne me silence, from henceforth
I'le practise talke to weary all thy sex.
I will be all, the everlasting talker,
And raile upon all women, till I have worne
My tongue to`th roote, I'le study presently
A satyre that shall eate thee through the bones,
And send thee first to an Hospitall.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: I see I am a foole, a melancholy
Suspitious foole, and all my plotts are nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Lett's follow, and eyther make him mad outright,
Or bring it to a cure, your part's not done yet.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Pl.
SP.L: This will undoe me, now must I to Prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: What dost thou thinke they meane Oldrat?

SP.SPEAKER: Old.
SP.L: I thinke? I hope they meane well.
And lovingly, and let us like honest servants
Into the sellar and pray for'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: A match.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Lord, Sir Walter, and Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Then nothing will prevaile but we must fight?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: And no place more convenient, draw sir Walter,
And Captaine, now indifferent friend to both,
For I have no suspition thou canst slaine
Thy selfe by partiality, witnes with
The hart I bring, I have no thought so blacke,
As murder, or revenge, but to preserue
My honor, which no balme can cure, if once
But the suspect of coward fall upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir
SP.L: I am not so unjust my Lord to doubt your courage.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: you have given proofe my Lord abroad,
That you dare fight.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Though I affect no glory
From actions of this nature, yet the World
At home must be convinc'd, our fame is lost else:
Had Peregrine beene coward, or not knowne
For valour, I had runne lesse hazard of
My fame, by being silent, but as I am
Beneath him in opinion, a yong man
Circled with expectation of something,
That must declare mee worthy of a name,
And love of men, I must attempt this danger:
But let me tell thee this, which perhaps may
Render thy sword more fatall to mee, I
Did love thy Lady with a sinfull purpose,
Persued ever persecuted her chast soule,
To satisfie my wantonnesse, but found
An innocence so rich in her, as may
Alone excuse the ill of all her sex,
Nor has the goodnesse only the effect
To preserue her, but it return'd my eyes
With so much shame upon my selfe, that I
Threw off my lust, and doted on her virtue,
Heaven shut his mercy up if I dissemble,
This injust obligation to cherish,
I did reward with trifles, which perhaps
Gave fewell to your jealousie, but know
I have design'd a larger recompence,
Which your sword may confirme to her in few minuts,
For if I chaunce fall by it, shee is declar'd
The heire to my estate, and she deserues it,
Which sheele employ no question to assure
Your peace, and pardon for my death, come on, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: I am more lost then ever, let my wonder
Be past, or you will fight against a man
Whose soul's a great way off. Didst heare this Captaine?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: With pardon of your Lordship, since you have
Declard so freely, what I thinke winnes credit
With him too, your intentions to his Lady:
There is no cause, you should engage your bloods, To any losse

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: You are my preserver, sir,
Make me not so ingratefull to advance
My sword against your life, that gave me all
The benefit of mine, I have assurance
Enough of you, and my wives honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Ther's
A purse of gold is troublesome, it may
Be usefull to'th surviver, come, sir, fight
By thy owne Ladies virtue, I shall else provoke you rudelie.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: For her sake my Lord, we should bee friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: That wonot helpe my fame,
Nor yours, if you regard what threatens it,
I must not live upon the charity
Of peoples tongues, their justice shall acknowledge
I doe not feare to bleed, let it be argument
To inflame thee, that thou majest be happyer
Vpon my losse, since my last minute gives
Thy wife possession of all my fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: That rather charmes me from each violence.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: This must compell you then, till now I never
Thought thee ingratefull, by thy fame I charge thee,
By thy Bellamias love, fight not with pitty,
Let me bee worthy at least to fall with honor,
Fight so, as howsoever fate determine,
I may get honor, though in death, and not
Suffer without a wound.
So her's some blood yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: I did but imitate my Lord your Character,

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Blood of both sides, nay then I interpose,
As you are gentlemen, for other titles
Weigh nothing here, be just to both your honors,
You have done well, exceeding well, unlesse
I shall conclude ther's malice on one side,
Be your selves now, and on such noble termes
Be reconcil'd agen, sir Walter is
No enemy at hart, and the World must
Be satisfied my Lord, in your just valor,
Thinke what blest providence has mark'd you both
For noble ends.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: I'le trust him with my sword,
Which rather shall make next impression here,
Then be his danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: I am overcome, take me thy Captiue.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: My most honord friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: So, so, 'tis faire on both sides, but my Lord,
You bleed much, can you spare it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Well enough, I'le wait upon you home.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: First have a Surgeon.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: What for a serath? let me present thee safe,
To thy Bellamia, shee but with a smile
Can cure all wounds, come Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Wee both waite on you.

DIV2.STAGE: Exeunt▪ Enter Jacintha, and Lady Peregrine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: You tell mee wonders.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel,
SP.L: I shall much repent
My discourse to thee, if it did not raise
Thy admiration, 'tis a noble Lord,
Thou art bound to make him restitution.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Of what?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Of fame, you were jealous of our honours.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: I have read the Chronicles, but never met
With a yong Lord has done the like.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: To what
Virtue in time will he grow to Jacintha?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Virtue? ther's another thing, not usuall
In men of his ranke, I allow a Gentleman
To pay his owne debts, but another mans,
Want's a record, besides all this, to love
Another mans wife, a hansome woman too,
And be at cost to keepe her honest? miracles.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: What joyes flow in my hart. Thou art sad fister.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: No sadnesse, but I have another passion, that troubles me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: You'le bee in time converted,
And leave your wild invectives against men,
Tis possible you may marry, if you could
Finde such another man to be your husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: No, I wood not.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Finde such another man to be my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Thou woodst have him, how now my witty sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: It cannot be conceal'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: Has litle Cupid
Beene practising with his bird-bolt, if thou bee'st not,
I'le wish thee hartelie in love, to punish
Thy want of charitie against all men
And marriage, 'tis but justice, nay be not melancholie;
He will be here presentlie.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: He shall be welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: He shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Be very welcome hither, he once said
If I remember well, could he but love,
He would marrie mee of all women alive.
My fortun's not to bee dispisd, however
My hart is rich enough, but it shall languish
To death, ere I will tell him so.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Lord, Sir walter, and Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: But do'st love him
Indeed? now but for pitie I could laugh.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: You may triumph sister, you have cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: And thou canst have no argument to despaire,
Come shall I tell my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.L: That thou lovest him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: Doe him not so much iniurie, my passion
Can still walke in disguise, though I confesse
Since your relation, 'tis become more troublesome
To be confin'd, oh love! I never thought
To have felt thy sting, I dare not stay to see him;
I shall betray my selfe with many blushes:
Farewell my Lord Fitzavarice.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Not so
Hee'le rather meet a welcome to his bosomo,
Repent not Lady, y'are but lovinglie
Betraid, and 'tis my happinesse, I should
Have pleaded at this barre, in this prevention
I am doubly blest, be constant, and devide
With me both hart, and fortunes: thou must needs
Be excellently good in being her sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: I must confesse my Lord, I honor you.
But not for any titles, although some
Woman may be allow'd the ambition,
But for your noble nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: I am confirm'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W.
SP.L: But all is well agen, and must exalt
Thy truer joyes by finding us both live,
And knit into a peace no time can violate,

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Let me salute The Example of chast honor;
Sister I now must call thee, and shall glorie
To owne that title by Jacinthas love.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir W. La.
SP.L: All blessings crowne your wishes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: I have a hart to wish you joyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: They will bee all a debt
To your noble care of us, Master Confident.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.L: One of my servants but not yet discharg'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: You come to turne and winde this Ladies fancie
With your wit now, but your devices fadge not,
It is three minutes since shee was dispos'd of,
And though my stocke of braine will not reach, to
Make a large joynture of so many hundred
Sonnets per annum, and rare Elegies,
Some fresh, and some that ha laine 7. yeeres pickled,
In other languages: yet sheele be content
With a lesse witty fortune, my estate sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Tis happinesse enough for mee
To snuffe your marriage Taper, whose bright shine
Shall put out the Worlds eye.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Spare, spare your fancies.
But I'le not now arraigne you, if you meane
To have me, know me agen, chafer some wit
Away for honesty, I conceale your shame,

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: Ther's hope then of your pardon, when I rise
From what has iustiie forfeited my name,
To shew the World your childing is not lost,
Your Lordship will not be asham'd agen
To owne me for your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: I shall be a glad witnes and admirer.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.L: Wilt please you gentlemen to have a Song.
Sir Solitary, and my Lady are at it, he is growne
The most Joviall gentleman—harke.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Pl.
SP.L: Welcome welcome, agen to thy wits.
This is a holy day.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.L: I'le have no plotts, nor melancholy fitts
But merily passe the time away:
They are mad, that are sad.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Pl.
SP.L: Bee ruld by mee;
And none shall bee so merry as wee.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.L: The kitchin shall catch cold no more.

SP.SPEAKER: La.
SP.L: I'le have no Key to the buttery dore,

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: The Fidlers shall sing,
The House shall ring,
And the World shall see.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: What a merry couple.
Merry couple.
Couple, couple,
wee will bee.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter sir Solitary, and his Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: Wee are new married Gentlemen, I must
Invite your Lordship for my guest. Your Tunes
Are melancholie. Welcome home my wandring nephew;
You shall bee welcome too, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: I'me your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir.
SP.L: When shall we dance Jacintha?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Sure this humor
Is very yong, pray Madam is he serious?
Is there no plott in this?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Pl.
SP.L: Beyond my hope
He is recover'd sir, and I must stand too't,
And turne a miracle, a Lady huswife.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sol.
SP.L: No more, least with the ioy I runne into
A madnes worse, then melancholie, you tell
Mee wonders: blesse my senses. And shall we dance?

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: I am for any mirth, the day requires it,
In which love too long blind hath found his eyes,
And leads the way to his owne Paradise.

DIV1.HEAD: Epilogue.
DIV1.L: PRaise a faire day at night the Proverbe sayes,
And 'tis the evening that must crowne all Playes.
For although writers may bee first allowd,
To speake themselves, their judgements are too proud
That waving all authority beside
Thinke 'tis enough when they are satisfied,
Wee must appeale to you, vnles you smile
Wee have but cherish'd vaine hopes all this while,
But if you like, by this we shall best prove it,
You'le follow The Example, if you love it.
